questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for evaluation of bilateral lower leg pain for the past two weeks. The patient recently started playing lacrosse and has been participating in practices or games six days per week. The pain worsens with running, tends to be more noticeable at the end of activity, and improves with rest. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals diffuse tenderness at the distal medial tibial borders without point tenderness. There is no noticeable swelling or erythema. Dorsalis pedis pulses are 2+, capillary refill is <2 seconds, and lower extremity sensation is intact. The patient ambulates effectively with minimal pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with findings concerning for shin splints, a common pediatric overuse injury. On physical examination, there will typically be diffuse tenderness on the mid to distal medial tibial borders without focal point tenderness.         

Common pediatric musculoskeletal injuries include fractures, sprains, joint subluxations, and overuse injuries. Differentiating these conditions relies heavily on a thorough history and physical examination. Key elements include the mechanism of injury, aggravating and relieving factors, and any prior injury to the area. A history of direct trauma, repetitive activity, or no clear trauma helps narrow the differential. Falls are a frequent cause of traumatic injury, while running and repetitive sports activities, such as pitching in baseball, commonly lead to overuse injuries. Also, history should be evaluated for consistency with the severity, pattern, mechanism, and timing of the injury, and the child’s developmental and mobility status. Any discrepancies should prompt a high index of suspicion for non-accidental trauma.       

The physical examination should assess for visible deformities, swelling, range of motion (both active and passive), neurovascular integrity, and the presence or absence of bony point tenderness.       

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Shin splints:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Osgood-Schlatter disease :
Incorrect: Osgood-Schlatter disease presents as pain and point tenderness over the tibial tubercle. This patient’s symptoms are localized to the shins and lack focal tenderness, making shin splints a more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Patellofemoral pain syndrome:
Incorrect: Patellofemoral pain syndrome presents with medial or lateral patellar tenderness. This patient's pain is along the medial tibial borders, which is more consistent with shin splints.  
❌ Greenstick fracture:
Incorrect: A greenstick fracture is unlikely for this patient given the absence of acute trauma, localized point tenderness, and swelling. This patient’s history is more consistent with an overuse injury, like shin splints. 
❌ Sever disease:
Incorrect: Sever disease presents with heel pain and tenderness of the lateral and medial calcaneus. This patient's tenderness is along the medial tibial borders and is consistent with shin splints.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of left elbow pain. A caregiver reports the child was having a temper tantrum at the mall when the caregiver pulled the child by the left arm to go home. The patient immediately began crying and refused to use the left arm. There was no fall or direct trauma to the elbow. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no daily medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals guarding of the left arm, which is held in slight flexion and pronation. There is no evidence of obvious injury or deformity to the left elbow. Capillary refill and sensation are intact. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Extension of the elbow and hyperpronation of the forearm

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with classic findings of nursemaid’s elbow, or radial head subluxation. History typically involves direct longitudinal traction applied to the affected arm, and physical examination reveals the arm held in slight flexion and pronation. Diagnosis is clinical, and plain radiographs are not routinely needed. Treatment involves reduction using either extension of the elbow and hyperpronation of the forearm or supination with flexion at the elbow.       

Common musculoskeletal injuries in children include fractures, sprains, joint dislocations or subluxation, and overuse injuries. Accurate diagnosis relies heavily on a thorough history and physical examination. Categorizing the injury based on a history of direct trauma, no identifiable trauma, or repetitive stress can help narrow the differential.       

When clinically indicated, plain radiographs of the affected bone and adjacent joints can be obtained to evaluate for fracture or dislocation. However, in certain conditions (e.g., nursemaid’s elbow, little league elbow) the diagnosis is often made clinically, and imaging is not typically needed. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may be considered when diagnostic uncertainty persists or when soft tissue injury is suspected. In cases concerning for non-accidental trauma, particularly in nonverbal children, those with limited communication, or those under 60 months of age, a skeletal survey should be performed.       

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Extension of the elbow and hyperpronation of the forearm:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Radiograph of the left elbow:
Incorrect: Imaging is not routinely indicated when the presentation is consistent with radial head subluxation, and there are no signs of deformity or trauma. Radiographs may be considered if the diagnosis is unclear or if symptoms persist after reduction. 
❌ Long arm splint:
Incorrect: Immobilization is not indicated for radial head subluxation. Prompt reduction is typically curative, and children usually resume use of the arm shortly afterward. 
❌ Sling placement with orthopedic follow-up:
Incorrect: Sling placement and specialist referral are unnecessary for radial head subluxation unless symptoms persist after reduction or another diagnosis is suspected. 
❌ Direct longitudinal forearm traction:
Incorrect: Longitudinal forearm traction is the mechanism that typically results in radial head subluxation. Reduction can be achieved by extension of the elbow and hyperpronation of the forearm or supination with flexion at the elbow.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with a 3-week history of a limp and pain while walking. A parent reports that the patient recently began playing basketball but has been lagging during running drills due to pain. The parent also notes a remote history of trauma at age six, when the child fell off a table and landed on his left hip. Vital signs are within normal limits. Weight is 90 kg (>97th percentile for age) and height is 165 cm. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the left hip without visible deformity. There is external rotation of the hip with passive flexion. The patient ambulates with a limp. Plain radiographs are obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia; Public domain.

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the hip

questions.solution:
Top: Displacement of the femoral head in relation to the neck on radiograph. Bottom: Radiograph after surgical fixation of the femoral head to the femoral neck. Reproduced from Wikipedia; Public domain.       

This patient, older than 10 years and with obesity, presents with a limp and hip pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation, passive flexion prompts external rotation of the hip, and radiographs show displacement of the femoral head relative to the femoral neck, consistent with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). Management requires urgent orthopedic consultation for in situ fixation to prevent further slippage and complications.        

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) and Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) are distinct pediatric hip disorders that commonly present with a limp. SCFE occurs when weakness at the growth plate causes the femoral head to slip posteriorly and inferiorly relative to the neck. In contrast, LCPD results from disrupted blood supply to the femoral head, leading to avascular necrosis. Clinical history, physical examination, and imaging help distinguish between the two. Key differentiating features are summarized in the chart below.   



Option Analysis

✅ Orthopedic consultation for surgical fixation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rest and physical therapy:
Incorrect: Rest and physical therapy are not appropriate for initial management of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), this patient’s diagnosis. Definitive treatment requires surgical stabilization to prevent further slippage and complications. Physical therapy may be considered only after fixation. 
❌ Ibuprofen and limited weight-bearing:
Incorrect: This strategy is commonly used in the management of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, not slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), this patient’s diagnosis. SCFE requires urgent orthopedic referral and surgical intervention, not conservative management. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the hip:
Incorrect: While MRI can be useful in early or atypical cases of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) when radiographs are inconclusive, this patient presents with classic findings on X-ray. An MRI is unnecessary. 
❌ Petrie casting:
Incorrect: Petrie casting is used in the management of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease and is not indicated for slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), this patient’s diagnosis. This technique involves bilateral long leg casts with a connecting bar to maintain hip abduction.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of low back pain. The patient is participating in gymnastics training and has had difficulty preparing for an upcoming competition due to persistent low back pain that is worse with movement and relieved with rest. The patient is otherwise healthy. He has not had any recent injury or trauma. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the low back is noted to be hyperlordotic. Pain is elicited with passive extension of the back. The straight leg test is negative bilaterally. A radiograph of the lumbar spine is shown below. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Repetitive stress on the pars interarticularis

questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents for evaluation of low back. Imaging reveals grade 1 L4 on L5 spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis refers to anterior displacement of the vertebral body with respect to the adjacent vertebral bodies. Spondylolisthesis can be caused by degenerative changes in the spine in adult patients. It can also be congenital and seen in children. In both adolescents and children, pars defects can be caused by overuse of the low back, mainly from sports that involve repetitive back bend-like motion. This can lead to fracture of the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis) which may progress to anterior subluxation of one vertebral body with respect to an adjacent vertebral body (spondylolisthesis).  

Lumbar spondylolisthesis can present with intermittent localized low back pain. The pain is typically worsened with  flexing and extending at the affected segment of the vertebrae. There may be pain with direct palpation on physical examination. Patients can also have radicular pain if the exiting nerve roots become compressed.  

Radiography is the initial test for diagnosing spondylolisthesis. CT of the spine has the highest sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis and may be performed after spinal radiographs are completed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Repetitive stress on the pars interarticularis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Compression of L4 nerve root:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy most commonly results from bulging intervertebral discs. The symptoms often include low back pain with associated radiation down the lower extremities. A straight leg raise is often positive with this condition. This patient’s signs and symptoms are not consistent with lumbar radiculopathy.  
❌ Lytic bone lesions:
Incorrect: The above lumbar film does not demonstrate lytic bony lesions, which often appear as punched-out areas of bone.  
❌ Lumbar erector spinae weakness:
Incorrect: Weakness of the lumbar erector spinae can lead to low back pain.  However this would not increase the risk of spondylolisthesis seen in this patient’s radiograph.  
❌ Narrowing of the intraspinal canal:
Incorrect: Spinal stenosis is an uncommon condition in adolescent patients. It most commonly presents in elderly patients with pain that is worsened with walking or activity and is relieved by sitting, lying down, or bending forward at the waist.

questions.text: An 11-month-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother for a routine well-child exam. The patient started walking at 9 months of age, and the mother has noticed that her daughter has an uneven gait. Height and weight are in the 89th and 80th percentiles, respectively. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 95/59 mmHg and pulse is 132/min. Thigh-length discrepancy on the left and asymmetry of the gluteal skin folds are noted. There is decreased abduction and limited range of motion of the left hip. A bilateral hip radiograph shows delayed ossification and femoral head dislocation on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment at this time?

choices.text: Closed hip reduction and spica cast
Open hip reduction and abduction splint

questions.solution:
This 11-month-old infant has physical examination and radiographic findings consistent with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The most appropriate treatment based on this patient’s age is referral to a pediatric orthopedist for closed hip reduction followed by a spica cast.    

Treatment for DDH is based on patient age. For patients < 6 months of age, an abduction splint, such as a Pavlik harness, which maintains hip flexion and leg abduction, is the recommended treatment. Patients between 6 months and 2 years of age who have DDH can be treated with closed reduction of the hip joint followed by placement of a spica cast. Children > 2 years of age typically require open reduction of the hip joint followed by a spica cast.    

Following treatment, patients should have routine radiographs of the hips to ensure proper development until patients are skeletally mature. Routine radiographs are also useful to screen for late complications of DDH repair, such as osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Closed hip reduction and spica cast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Follow-up bilateral hip radiographs:
Incorrect: Follow-up radiography are helpful to ensure proper development and screen for late complications (e.g. osteonecrosis, osteoarthritis) in patients with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) who have received definitive treatment with surgery and splinting. This patient has not yet had treatment, which should include closed hip reduction and spica cast.   
❌ Open hip reduction and abduction splint:
Incorrect: Open hip reduction is generally reserved for children > 2 years of age who are diagnosed with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). Given this patient's age, closed hip reduction and spica cast is recommended.
❌ Pavlik harness:
Incorrect: An abduction splint, such as the Pavlik harness, is typically used to treat infants with DDH who are < 6 months of age. Given this patient's age, closed hip reduction and spica cast is recommended.
❌ Observation:
Incorrect: Observation of a pediatric patient with historical and examination findings suspicious for hip instability is not appropriate as it would delay definitive treatment and can result in complications.

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents for a routine well-child exam. The patient was born via an uneventful vaginal delivery at 39-weeks gestation. The patient appears well-developed, is active and attentive, and reacts normally to stimuli. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 97/60 mmHg, and pulse is 132/min. Physical examination of the infant in the supine position with the hips flexed reveals a palpable clunk while the hip is slowly abducted and the lateral thigh is pressed upward on the left side. Asymmetry of the gluteal skin folds is also seen. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Physical examination findings in this 3-month-old infant are strongly suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). A positive Ortolani maneuver (palpable “clunk”) was elicited during examination of the infant’s left hip. Because this infant is < 6 months of age, a bilateral hip ultrasound should be performed next to confirm the diagnosis of DDH.      

The Ortolani “clunk” and the Barlow “click” indicate hip joint instability and should be followed up in infants < 6 months of age with bilateral hip ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis of DDH. Patients with risk factors for DDH, which include family history of DDH or breech after 34 weeks gestation, should also have bilateral hip ultrasound as well. For patients > 6 months, these maneuvers are less sensitive and other signs and symptoms and exam findings should be used to screen for DDH. If DDH is suspected, these patients should have bilateral hip X-rays to confirm the diagnosis.    



Option Analysis

✅ Bilateral hip ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Spica cast:
Incorrect: A hip spica cast is typically placed after closed reduction of the hip in infants > 6 months of age that have been diagnosed with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). It is used to immobilize the hip and thigh to facilitate healing. Patients under 6 months of age with DDH are treated with an abduction splint or Pavlik harness after the diagnosis is confirmed with bilateral hip ultrasound.
❌ Open reduction of the hip:
Incorrect: Open reduction of the hip is used to treat confirmed cases of DDH in toddlers older than 2 years of age. This infant, who is less than 6 months of age with suspected DDH, should have bilateral hip ultrasound performed to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Closed reduction of the hip:
Incorrect: Closed reduction of the hip is generally reserved for infants between 6 months of age and 2 years of age who are diagnosed with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). This infant, who is less than 6 months of age with suspected DDH, should have bilateral hip ultrasound performed to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Radiographs of the bilateral hips:
Incorrect: Radiographs of the bilateral hips should be performed in patients > 6 months of age who are suspected of having developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). This infant, who is less than 6 months of age with suspected DDH, should have bilateral hip ultrasound performed to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents because of a limp that has developed over the past two days. The patient states that he does not have pain, but his parents have noticed him favoring the left leg. He had an upper respiratory infection one week ago which resolved on its own. Past medical history is unremarkable and immunizations are up-to-date. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 22/min. The patient is well-appearing but is limping with an antalgic gait on the right side. There is no swelling, redness, or warmth on the joint examination. Right hip motion is restricted, and mild pain is elicited with internal rotation of the hip. White blood cell count is 12,100, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is 22, and C-reactive protein (CRP) is 1.7. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and observation
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right hip

questions.solution:
This patient presents acutely with a limp and physical exam findings of limited right hip rotation and mild pain with internal rotation of the hip. He has a history of a recent upper respiratory infection (URI). Given that he has an elevated white blood cell count, ESR and CRP, the diagnosis should be confirmed with bilateral hip ultrasound and arthrocentesis should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and rule out septic arthritis.

Transient synovitis of the hip is characterized by transient inflammation of the synovium of the hip, typically affecting children aged 3-8 years and often following a URI. Patients can present with a limp and hip pain, and with the affected hip flexed, abducted, and externally rotated. Patients may be febrile. Laboratory findings can be normal or may show mild elevations in white blood cell (WBC) count, ESR and CRP. Transient synovitis of the hip is a diagnosis of exclusion. Radiographs may be normal. Bilateral hip ultrasound typically shows the presence of unilateral or bilateral effusions. Arthrocentesis may be necessary to rule out septic arthritis in patients who appear toxic, with fevers, and/or have significant elevations in white blood cell count, esr or crp. Management involves conservative measures including rest and non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Most children recover fully within 1-2 weeks, with recurrences being rare.  

Option Analysis

✅ Bilateral hip ultrasound with arthrocentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bilateral hip radiographs:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transient synovitis of the right hip. While radiographs can rule out bony abnormalities, they are less sensitive for detecting early joint effusions. Ultrasound is more appropriate in this case as it provides superior visualization of joint effusions, and ultrasound-guided arthrocentesis should be performed to rule out septic arthritis in this patient who has an elevated white blood cell count, ESR, and CRP.  
❌ Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and observation:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transient synovitis of the right hip for which non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are prescribed. However, an ultrasound with arthrocentesis should be performed on this patient to confirm the diagnosis and rule out septic arthritis.  
❌ Continued regular activity:
Incorrect: Rest and non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are typically recommended in the treatment of transient synovitis of the hip. Symptoms typically resolve within 2 weeks.  
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right hip:
Incorrect: An MRI is not typically the initial imaging for a child with a clinical picture suggestive of transient synovitis. It is reserved for cases where the diagnosis is unclear after initial assessment or for evaluating more complex hip pathologies.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy is evaluated in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for arm swelling noted by nursing staff. The infant was delivered at 27 weeks’ gestation due to preterm labor and was stabilized after immediate resuscitation. Birth weight was 970 grams. The hospital course is complicated by respiratory distress syndrome and a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) that was treated surgically. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 40/min, blood pressure is 50/32 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on nasal cannula with 25% FiO<sub>2</sub>. On physical examination, the left upper arm is swollen and tender to touch. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Alkaline phosphatase is 1057 U/L, and phosphorus is 1.8 mg/dL. A radiograph of the arm reveals an oblique fracture of the shaft of the left humerus. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s fracture?
questions.solution:
This 6-week-old infant was born at 27 weeks’ gestation. Physical examination is pertinent for swelling and tenderness of the upper arm, and radiographs confirm an isolated humerus fracture. Laboratory results show elevated alkaline phosphatase and decreased phosphorus – findings consistent with osteopenia of prematurity.  

Osteopenia of prematurity results from reduced bone mineral content. Since intrauterine transfer of minerals primarily occurs during the third trimester, preterm infants lack the calcium and phosphorus stores required for adequate bone development, putting them at risk for osteopenia. Other risk factors include inadequate nutrient intake (e.g., calcium, phosphorus, vitamin D), prolonged total parenteral nutrition, and long-term corticosteroid use. Neonates with osteopenia are usually asymptomatic and are often identified through routine screening, although severe cases may present with fractures.

Osteopenia of prematurity is confirmed through labs and imaging. Low serum phosphorus and high alkaline phosphatase levels are suggestive of the condition. Radiographs may show fractures, growth plate widening, and poor bone mineralization.

Option Analysis

❌ Osteogenesis imperfecta:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder affecting type I collagen that typically presents with decreased bone density, bone fractures, blue sclerae, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and short stature. Skeletal surveys typically identify fractures at varying ages and stages of healing. This patient is premature with an elevated alkaline phosphatase, decreased phosphorus level, and an isolated fracture, making osteopenia of prematurity the most probable cause.
❌ Osteomyelitis:
Incorrect: Osteomyelitis is a bone infection typically presenting with temperature instability and focal signs of infection such as erythema, swelling, and warmth to touch. Radiographic findings include lytic lesions and a periosteal reaction. This patient is premature, does not have focal signs of infection, has an elevated alkaline phosphatase and decreased phosphorus level, and has no radiographic findings of osteomyelitis. Osteopenia of prematurity is the most probable cause of this patient’s fracture.
✅ Osteopenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osteopetrosis:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive osteopetrosis typically presents in infancy or early childhood with recurrent infections, easy bruising, bleeding abnormalities, pathologic fractures, macrocephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly. Radiographs often show osteosclerosis with a characteristic “marble bone” appearance, which is not seen in this patient. This patient is premature with an elevated alkaline phosphatase, decreased phosphorus level, and an isolated fracture, making osteopenia of prematurity the most probable cause of this patient’s fracture.
❌ Congenital syphilis:
Incorrect: Early congenital syphilis, when clinical manifestations present before two years of age, can result in irregular periosteal thickening, metaphyseal serration, and demineralization of the upper medial tibia on radiograph. This patient has an isolated fracture, and in the setting of prematurity and the aforementioned laboratory abnormalities, osteopenia of prematurity is the most probable cause.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of an abnormal gait. A caregiver reports that the child has been limping at home and struggling to keep up with friends at the park. The child is otherwise healthy with no prior medical issues and has been eating and drinking normally. There is no history of recent illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. When asked to stand on his right leg, the patient’s pelvis drops to the left. Examination of the right hip reveals anterior thigh muscle atrophy, and a shortened right leg compared to the left. Which of the following findings best supports the diagnosis?

choices.text: Positive family history of orthopedic disease
Limited internal rotation and abduction of the hip

questions.solution:
This biologically male patient under the age of 8 presents with an abnormal gait. Physical examination reveals a shortened right lower extremity, right anterior thigh muscle atrophy, and a positive Trendelenburg sign. These findings are consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD), which classically presents with a painless limp.      
 
Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) and slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) are distinct hip disorders that commonly present with a limp in children. LCPD results from disrupted blood supply to the femoral head, leading to avascular necrosis and subsequent deformity. In contrast, SCFE involves mechanical failure at the growth plate, causing displacement of the femoral head relative to the neck.        

Clinicians can distinguish between these conditions based on clinical history, physical examination, and imaging. A comparison of key differentiating features is provided in the chart above. 



Option Analysis

✅ Absence of pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Positive family history of orthopedic disease:
Incorrect: A positive family history may be present in both slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) and Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) and does not reliably distinguish between them. 
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity is a known risk factor for slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), which typically affects older children and adolescents. Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is more common in younger children and is often associated with lower body weight. 
❌ Limited internal rotation and abduction of the hip :
Incorrect: Both slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) and Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) can present with restricted internal rotation and abduction, making this a nonspecific finding. 
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: Fever is not characteristic of either slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) or Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) and raises concern for alternative diagnoses such as septic arthritis, which typically presents with acute onset, significant pain, and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pain with walking and a limp. His symptoms have progressively worsened over the past two weeks but became more severe today after stepping awkwardly off a curb. There is no significant medical history. The adolescent had a cold last week but has otherwise been in his usual state of health. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 132/78 mmHg, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On exam, weight is 98 kg (216 lbs.; > 99th percentile for age) and height is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in). The patient appears to be in pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the hip, and the leg externally rotates with passive hip flexion. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the hip

questions.solution:
This adolescent with obesity presents with a limp and hip pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the hip, and external rotation is observed with passive hip flexion. These findings are suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). The best initial diagnostic step is to obtain anteroposterior and frog-leg lateral radiographs of the pelvis. Imaging of the contralateral hip is also recommended due to the high prevalence of bilateral involvement.       

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) and Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) are distinct conditions that can present with a limp in children. SCFE is caused by mechanical failure at the growth plate, resulting in posterior and inferior displacement of the femoral head. In contrast, LCPD results from disruption of the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to osteonecrosis and subsequent deformation.        

When either SCFE or LCPD is suspected, bilateral hip radiographs should be obtained. If radiographs are unremarkable and clinical suspicion remains high, MRI may be warranted to detect early or subtle changes. In SCFE, radiographs typically show displacement of the femoral head, while MRI may demonstrate physeal widening and surrounding bone marrow edema. In LCPD, radiographs may reveal joint space widening, flattening, or fragmentation of the femoral head in more advanced stages. MRI can detect early ischemic changes through evidence of decreased perfusion to the femoral head.   

Option Analysis

✅ Plain radiographs of the hip :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ultrasound of the hip:
Incorrect: Ultrasound of the hip is a useful test to evaluate a joint effusion but is not appropriate for evaluating structural abnormalities such as slipped capital femoral epiphysis. 
❌ Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) :
Incorrect: Inflammatory markers can support a diagnosis of septic arthritis or transient synovitis but are not indicated in the absence of systemic signs of infection. Transient synovitis typically occurs in younger children and presents with less pain and preserved range of motion.  
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the hip:
Incorrect: MRI may detect early or radiographically occult disease but is only necessary when the diagnosis cannot be made with standard radiographs.
❌ Hip arthrocentesis:
Incorrect: Arthrocentesis is reserved for suspected joint infection or inflammatory arthritis. This patient lacks signs of infection such as fever, erythema, or marked joint effusion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of right anterior leg pain. She recently joined a fitness program that required resistance training and two hours of brisk walking. The pain is worse at the beginning of exercise and decreases throughout the workout. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diffuse tenderness along the posteromedial aspect of the right shin. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. X-ray of the right lower extremity reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with diffuse tenderness over the posteromedial aspect of the right shin, consistent with medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS), also known as shin splints.  

MTSS is commonly seen in casual runners or in individuals following sudden changes in physical activity. Other risk factors include flare feet, rigid arches, or exercising with improper or worn-out footwear. MTSS is thought to result from inflammation of the anterior and posterior calf musculature and periostitis of the tibia. The most common symptoms of MTSS include diffuse pain along the posteromedial border of the tibia that worsens with running. It is important to differentiate MTSS from tibial stress fractures, which more commonly present with point tenderness, as the latter have potential complications if not cared for properly. Plain radiographs in patients with MTSS are usually normal.  



Option Analysis

❌ Exertional compartment syndrome:
Incorrect: Exertional compartment syndrome occurs in young athletes secondary to increased compartment pressures with exertion. Patients usually present with aching or burning pain in the leg within ten minutes of exercise that slowly resolves within 30-40 minutes following exercise. Diffuse shin tenderness is not typically present.  
✅ Medial tibial stress syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Tibial stress fractures can manifest with anterior leg pain, resembling that of medial tibial stress syndrome. This condition commonly occurs in underweight athletes and presents with point tenderness as opposed to diffuse tenderness.   
❌ Common fibular nerve compression:
Incorrect: The common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury as it courses laterally around the neck of the fibula. Clinically, it presents with weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion as well as sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and lateral shin and between first and second toe.   
❌ Interosseous ligament tear:
Incorrect: Interosseous ligament tear can occur in high ankle strains and presents with anterolateral ankle pain following a rotational force on a dorsiflexed ankle. This condition is commonly associated with fibula fractures. Diffuse tenderness along the posteromedial aspect of the shin is suggestive of medial tibial stress syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of left ankle pain. He was playing soccer when he accidentally rolled his ankle. Since then, he has developed severe left ankle pain and swelling. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an area of ecchymosis and point tenderness over the anterolateral aspect of the left ankle joint. Exacerbation of pain is noted with forced ankle inversion. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with left lateral ankle pain and significant swelling and ecchymosis, following an inversion injury, most likely suffered an ankle sprain.    

Ankle sprains are the most common ankle injury, and the majority involve the lateral ankle ligaments: the anterior talofibular ligament, the calcaneofibular ligament, and the posterior talofibular ligament. Damage to these ligaments occurs following extreme inversion of the ankle with plantar flexion. The most common ankle sprain involves the anterior talofibular ligament and patients typically present with pain and ecchymosis at the anterolateral aspect of the ankle. Eversion injuries are much less common, and can result in an avulsion fracture of the medial malleolus, leading to joint instability and possible nerve injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Anterior talofibular ligament sprain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior tibialis tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Anterior tibialis tendon rupture is uncommon and presents with "slapping gait," as the patient is unable to actively dorsiflex the ankle, resulting in the foot slapping the ground with each step. An inversion of a plantar-flexed ankle most commonly results in anterior talofibular ligament sprain.  
❌ Syndesmotic sprain:
Incorrect: Syndesmotic sprains usually result from dorsiflexion and/or eversion of the ankle and affects the anterior tibiofibular, the posterior tibiofibular, the transverse tibiofibular ligaments, and the interosseous membrane. Affected patients present with unstable ankles and tenderness at the distal tibiofibular joints.  
❌ Deltoid ligament sprain:
Incorrect: Deltoid ligament sprain is uncommon, but can result from forced eversion of the ankle and an avulsion fracture of the medial malleolus. The pain of a deltoid ligament sprain is accentuated by eversion of the ankle, not inversion.  
❌ Achilles tendon rupture:
Incorrect: The gastrocnemius and the soleus tendon combine to form the Achilles tendon. Its rupture can occur during strenuous physical activities that involve sudden pivots or rapid acceleration. Tenderness and ecchymosis of the Achilles tendon is noted in affected patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of new-onset gait difficulties. The patient received a right-sided gluteal intramuscular injection at her orthopedist's office three days ago for shoulder pain. She does not have bowel or bladder symptoms or lower extremity pain. She never had trouble walking before and had no gait problems at her appointment three days ago. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient leans toward her right side with ambulation. When asked to stand on the right leg, the patient’s left pelvis tilts downwards. Intragluteal injection at which of the following anatomic sites is responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Superior portion of the posterior thigh

questions.solution:
This patient’s gait disturbance is consistent with a Trendelenburg gait, characterized by a contralateral hip drop of the unaffected side while walking due to the weakness of the gluteus medius. This muscle is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1), which was most likely injured secondary to intramuscular injection over the superomedial quadrant of the right buttock.  

The superolateral quadrant of the buttock serves as the safest site for dorsogluteal injections. It can be located by dividing the buttock into four using a cross shape and administering the injection in the upper outer quadrant. This region, however, is at some risk of superior gluteal or sciatic nerve injury. Most intragluteal injections target the ventrolateral gluteal area, which is in a triangle formed by the anterior superior iliac spine and the iliac crest.

Option Analysis

❌ Superolateral quadrant of the buttock:
Incorrect: The superolateral quadrant of the buttock is the safest gluteal region to administer intramuscular injections.
❌ Inferolateral quadrant of the buttock:
Incorrect: The inferolateral quadrant is a high-risk area for potential sciatic nerve injury. Sciatic nerve injury presents with knee flexion and ankle plantarflexion weakness, paresthesias, and loss of sensation rather than Trendelenburg gait.
✅ Superomedial quadrant of the buttock:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferomedial quadrant of the buttock:
Incorrect: The inferomedial quadrant is a high-risk area for potential sciatic nerve injury. Sciatic nerve injury presents with knee flexion and ankle plantarflexion weakness, paresthesias, and loss of sensation rather than Trendelenburg gait.
❌ Superior portion of the posterior thigh:
Incorrect: The superior portion of the posterior thigh is a high-risk region for sciatic nerve injury due to its large size as it passes into the thigh. Sciatic nerve injury presents knee flexionankle plantarflexion  weakness, paresthesia, and loss of sensation rather than a Trendelenburg gait.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with right ankle pain for three weeks. He describes the pain as being worse in the morning and improving with activity throughout the day. He denies recent trauma but notes that he recently started training for a marathon. He has a past medical history significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus managed with an insulin pump. His most recent HbA1c was 5.8%. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation and swelling over the posterior aspect of the ankle and foot. There is increased pain at the back of the ankle and foot with dorsiflexion of the foot. There is no erythema or warmth. Examination of the left foot is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Achilles tendinopathy is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. It is a common overuse injury that is often seen in athletes, especially patients like this one who have increased their training intensity. The pain associated with Achilles tendinopathy is typically worse in the morning and improves with activity as the tendon stretches throughout the day. Physical examination often reveals tenderness to palpation and swelling along the Achilles tendon and over the tendinous insertion sites at the posterior aspect of the ankle. The pain is typically exacerbated by dorsiflexion of the foot.

Both historical features and physical examination findings are important for formulating a differential diagnosis for an adult who presents with ankle pain. A history of trauma suggests sprains, strains, or fractures; while systemic symptoms (e.g. fever, malaise) may indicate septic arthritis or osteomyelitis. Recent increases in physical activity can point towards overuse injuries like tendinopathies. Physical exam findings such as tenderness, erythema, warmth, swelling, and pain with range motion can help differentiate between fractures, arthritis, and infection. Neurological signs like decreased sensation suggest neuropathic pain, and skin changes may indicate dermatologic or infectious causes.   

Option Analysis

❌ Osteomyelitis:
Incorrect: Patients with osteomyelitis typically present with constitutional symptoms, such as fever and elevated inflammatory markers. They typically have a history of risk factors like diabetic neuropathy or peripheral vascular disease. This patient has a history of well-controlled diabetes and no systemic symptoms or signs of infection. 
❌ Neuropathic pain:
Incorrect: Neuropathic pain is characterized as burning, lancinating, or radiating pain, often accompanied by paresthesia. This patient's pain is mechanical in nature, worsening with dorsiflexion, and is associated with a recent increase in physical activity. 
❌ Septic arthritis:
Incorrect: Patients with septic arthritis present with the acute onset of severe joint pain, swelling, erythema, and systemic symptoms (e.g. fever). The more chronic nature of this patient’s pain and absence of systemic signs or symptoms makes septic arthritis unlikely. 
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis typically involves multiple joints of the hands and feet in a symmetrical distribution and is accompanied by systemic symptoms, such as fatigue and prolonged morning stiffness. This patient's isolated ankle pain without systemic signs or polyarticular involvement does not fit the typical presentation of rheumatoid arthritis.  
✅ Achilles tendinopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of left foot pain. The patient recently joined a fitness program that requires her to walk two to three miles daily. The pain begins with her first steps and worsens throughout her daily walks. The pain improves with rest and does not recur with normal daily activities. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a normal left and right foot arch. Direct pressure applied to the bottom of the left heel elicits a sharp pain. Mediolateral squeezing of the heels does not elicit pain. There is tenderness to palpation between the left heel and forefoot when the left toes are dorsiflexed. The remainder of the bilateral lower extremity examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve
Inflammation and degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis

questions.solution:
This patient’s heel pain is most likely due to the inflammation and degeneration of plantar aponeurosis, resulting in plantar fasciitis. 

Plantar aponeurosis is a thick fibrous band that extends from the calcaneus of the foot to the toes, which functions to support the longitudinal arch of the foot. Plantar fasciitis results from chronic overuse and repetitive trauma to aponeurosis near its insertion point at the calcaneus. Risk factors include obesity, excessive foot pronation, excessive running, and prolonged standing. Patients typically present with stabbing heel pain that worsens with walking and may worsen after activity or at the end of the day. Physical examination often demonstrates tenderness at the insertion of the plantar fascia on the calcaneus, especially with toe dorsiflexion. 

The diagnosis is based on clinical findings, but plain radiographs may reveal heel spurs, which are of little diagnostic significance. Plantar fasciitis is a self-limited condition with most resolution of symptoms within twelve months. Initial treatment consists of ice, heat, massage, stretching, and elimination of exacerbating activities.   

Option Analysis

❌ Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve :
Incorrect: Injury or compression of the posterior tibial nerve at the tarsal tunnel may result in numbness or paraesthesias over the sole of the foot. Pain is reproduced with percussion of the tarsal tunnel (Tinel sign) and not by the palpation of the heel. 
❌ Neuropathic degeneration of interdigital nerves :
Incorrect: Neuropathic degeneration of interdigital nerves can result in a Morton neuroma, which presents with pain between the third and fourth toes on the plantar surface and a clicking sensation upon squeezing the metatarsal joints. Tenderness of the heel with dorsiflexion of the toes is typical of plantar fasciitis. 
✅ Inflammation and degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Overuse injury of the calcaneus :
Incorrect: Calcaneal stress fractures can occur following the initiation of high-impact exercise programs or overuse. It causes pain at the heel that worsens with weight bearing. Pain is often elicited by firm palpation at the lateral and medial aspect of the heel. Tenderness of the heel reproduced on dorsiflexion of toes is more typical for plantar fasciitis. 
❌ Neurogenic arthropathy :
Incorrect: Neurogenic arthropathy (charcot joint) presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma, secondary to imapired proprioception and pain sensations. Therefore, pain is typically mild in these patients.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of right shoulder pain for the past several weeks. The patient describes the pain as dull and generalized and has noted that the pain worsens with overhead movements. The patient experienced a fall while rock climbing several weeks ago during which he landed directly onto his right shoulder. He immediately felt pain in the anterior shoulder. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination does not demonstrate obvious deformity, swelling, or warmth over the right shoulder. The patient has full range of motion of the right shoulder but notes worsening pain with abduction and elevation of the shoulder. The patient is asked to flex the shoulder, extend at the elbow, and internally rotate with the arm until the thumb is pointing downward. When the examiner pushes the arm to the floor while the patient resists, there is deep shoulder pain. When the patient’s arm is supinated and the examiner pushes down, there is no pain. An X-ray of the right shoulder is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of traumatic shoulder pain. He experiences pain in the anterior shoulder that worsens with overhead movements and a positive O’brien test, which is highly suggestive of a labral tear. The next best step is to obtain a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the shoulder to confirm the diagnosis radiographically.        

Shoulder pain is a common symptom with many underlying causes, including conditions affecting the joint, capsule, tendons, or bursa. When performing a history and physical examination for a patient with shoulder pain, the first step is to identify if the patient’s shoulder pain is due to trauma or infection.    

When a clear history of trauma is present, further diagnostic differentiation can often be achieved by a combination of physical examination maneuvers and imaging. For example, patients with a shoulder dislocation or AC separation will typically have an obvious deformity of the shoulder that may be detected by X-ray. Patients with a labral tear or rotator cuff pathology will exhibit pain with certain physical examination maneuvers like the O’brien test or the drop arm test. Patients with trauma and positive physical exam signs of labral tear or rotator cuff pathology should undergo additional imaging with MRI to confirm the diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

✅ Labral tear:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acromioclavicular separation :
Incorrect: While a positive O’brien test as seen in this patient may indicate AC separation as well as labral pathology, there is no evidence of AC separation radiographically. Additionally, patients with AC separation often have a visible deformity on physical exam. 
❌ Anterior shoulder dislocation:
Incorrect: Patients with a shoulder dislocation typically have evidence of a severely limited range of motion at the shoulder. The shoulder typically appears “squared off.” Moreover, this patient's X-ray does not demonstrate a dislocation. 
❌ Osteoarthritis :
Incorrect: This patient has a normal X-ray without joint space narrowing or osteophyte formation that would be suggestive of arthritis. Moreover, osteoarthritis would be unlikely in this young, healthy patient.  
❌ Humeral head fracture:
Incorrect: This patient has a normal X-ray without evidence of fracture or dislocation despite this patient's history of direct trauma to the shoulder.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office because of left thigh pain and numbness. The patient’s symptoms started two days after a 12-hour tech rehearsal for a Shakespearen play. She was wearing her costume, which includes a corset, and noticed numbness and burning sensation over the lateral side of her left thigh following the rehearsal. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates loss of light touch and pinprick sensation over the upper lateral thigh. Lower extremity strength is 5/5 bilaterally, and deep tendon reflexes are +2. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. Pain is reproduced with tapping immediately below the anterior superior iliac spine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is a mononeuropathy resulting from the compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN) which travels from the lumbar plexus, through the abdominal cavity, under the inguinal ligament, and into the subcutaneous tissue of the thigh. Commonly identified risk factors include pregnancy, tight-fitted clothes/seat belts, obesity, and diabetes mellitus. Affected patients present with pain, paresthesias (numbness and tingling), and hypoesthesia (diminished sensation) over the upper outer thigh. Muscle strength, however, is normal as the LFCN does not carry motor fibers. Symptoms may be reproduced with tapping over the lateral aspect of the inguinal ligament (Tinel's sign).    

Diagnosis is clinical, and most patients are managed with weight loss and avoidance of exacerbating factors (e.g. avoiding tight-fitted clothing). Anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin, or gabapentin) can help reduce neuropathic pain in patients with refractory symptoms.   

Option Analysis

❌ Compression of the ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal nerve innervates the medial thigh, inguinal region, and lower abdomen. Compression or injury of this nerve can occur during pelvic or hernia surgery. 
✅ Wearing tight fitting clothes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Prolonged strenuous activity is associated with the development of stress fractures. This condition presents as dull, chronic pain of the affected region (e.g. lateral hip pain in femoral head stress fracture). Burning pain and paraesthesia over the lateral thigh is suggestive of cutaneous nerve compression injury.
❌ Femoral neuropathy:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve innervates the anteromedial skin of the thigh (via the medial femoral cutaneous branch) as well as medial lower leg via the saphenous nerve. Femoral neuropathy is associated with diminished or absent knee jerk reflexes. 
❌ Increased intracompartmental pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intracompartmental pressure occurs in patients with acute compartment syndrome, which more commonly develops following a severe injury–such as a car accident or long bone fracture. It typically causes severe pain, paresthesia, and weakness of the affected limb.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of foot pain. She started hiking recently to lose some weight. The patient reports dull, achy pain at the left medial ankle. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates pain with palpation posterior to the medial malleolus. Upon weight bearing and gait analysis, the physician notes a collapse of the medial longitudinal arch, outward tilted heels, valgus hindfoot deformity, and forefoot abduction, as shown below. The rest of the examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is a common etiology of this patient’s presentation? 
 

Image obtained from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with foot pain during increased activity and collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing, suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction (PTTD). Over time, this condition results in an acquired flat foot (pes planus). 

Flatfoot is a progressive deformity characterized by the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch with forefoot abduction and hindfoot valgus. The most common etiology of acquired flatfoot is PTTD. Other causes include congenital ligamentous laxity (e.g., Marfan syndrome and pregnancy), degenerative or inflammatory arthropathies, and rheumatoid arthritis. 

Flatfoot may or may not be symptomatic. Patients may endorse dull, achy arch pain, medial ankle or heel pain, and a sensation of “muscle weakness” or fatigue with exercise. Physical examination demonstrates collapse of the medial longitudinal arch with weight bearing, the ‘too many toes’ sign (examiner can see all four toes when looking at the foot from behind), valgus hindfoot deformity, and forefoot abduction.       

Option Analysis

❌ Plantar aponeurosis inflammation :
Incorrect: Plantar fasciitis results from inflammation and degeneration of plantar aponeurosis, secondary to chronic overuse and repetitive trauma at its insertion site. Patients typically present with sharp and stabbing heel pain that is worse when walking and with tenderness at the insertion point of the plantar fascia on the calcaneus. Collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing is suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction.  
✅ Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Neuropathic Charcot changes :
Incorrect: Charcot joint presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma and impaired proprioception and sensation of pain. Collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing is suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction.  
❌ Fibularis tendon tendinopathy :
Incorrect: Patients with fibularis tendon tendinopathy present with pain, and occasionally, swelling and warmth of the posterolateral aspect of the ankle. 
❌ First metatarsophalangeal joint sprain :
Incorrect: First metatarsophalangeal joint sprains result from an injury to the big toe secondary to forced hyperextension. This patient does not have evidence of an isolated digit injury.
